Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the effectiveness of the ten tips in preventing coronavirus, as they are described as "misleading advice" and contradicted by official recommendations from reputable sources.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that drinking hot liquids and gargling with antiseptics are not proven methods to prevent or cure COVID-19, as stated by the World Health Organization and other health authorities.
Understate: There is no indication of understatement bias in the claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters by promoting misleading advice that is not supported by scientific evidence or official recommendations.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks support from credible sources and scientific evidence, as it is contradicted by the World Health Organization, health authorities, and experts.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the ten tips provided are effective in preventing coronavirus, despite the lack of evidence and contradicting information from reputable sources.
Exist alternative explanation: There is no alternative explanation bias in the claim.
